content.webTitle: Michael Carrick: Manchester United can pip champions City to second

fields.headline: Michael Carrick: Manchester United can pip champions City to second
fields.bodyText: Michael Carrick believes Manchester United are capable of catching Manchester City and beating them to second place in the Premier League. Carrick, who made a first league start for two months against Tottenham Hotspur at the weekend following a calf injury, scored United’s second in 3-0 win, including a first with his head for the club. And, following City’s 1-0 defeat at Burnley, United are just two points adrift of the champions before Sunday’s trip to Liverpool. “We’re within touching distance now, said the midfielder. “You look at the table now and it is so tight. But I suppose really we’ve just got to look to next Sunday. There are going to be ups and downs because that is how it is, especially in the last nine or 10 games. Sunday is a big game for a lot of reasons and that is probably all we can focus on at the moment. “For this club it’s [the Champions League] the place to be isn’t it?” the 33-year-old added. “We had been in it for so long and not being involved on the big nights [this season] makes you realise what it is all about.” He understands, however, that the pressure will now be cranked up in United’s remaining nine matches – beginning at Anfield. “Hopefully when that pressure kicks in, and it goes up and up, then we perform even better, and we’re going to have to in the weeks to come,” he said. The display against Spurs was United’s best under the current manager Louis van Gaal. What was the difference? “Sometimes it clicks and works well, sometimes it doesn’t work so well. It came together well [against Tottenham],” Carrick added. “We were a real threat going forward, we controlled the game well, and had a really good balance. We had a good tempo, we attacked with speed and we had penetration when we did go forward. We kept the ball when we had to and got the balance right really. All in all we can’t be too picky – it was a good all-round performance. “Tottenham are a good side, we knew that going into the game, and we’ve beaten them and we’ve picked up an important three points,” the player who cost £18.6m from the White Hart Lane club in June 2006 added. “But it doesn’t count for anything more than that. It will give us confidence, of course, but in terms of what it means to anyone else it is not for me to answer really. I think it is just more for us a big boost going into another big one [at Anfield].” The manner of the win offered some evidence that Van Gaal’s methods are finally working. “The players are behind him, of course,” Carrick said. “It is just that results prove everything don’t they? We can improve on the training pitch, we can get better there, but it is all about what we do on game day really. And it was probably a big step for us in terms of the size of the game and to play like we did I think will give everyone a big boost and big shot of confidence. “And it shows we are moving in the right direction, which is good. But it is no good settling for that. We still need to keep on that upward curve. I think it has to be our best performance of the season given the importance of the game. After the first few minutes, when we made a couple of little mistakes, I thought we controlled the game well and looked a real threat going forward. “ Obviously before the game we didn’t think it was going to be that easy, so we are over the moon with the result. It sets us up for another big game at Anfield on Sunday. Every game is important now, isn’t it?”
